title: SKETCH PAD; Growing Up, Not Out, in Brooklyn

title: F. Y. I.

body: WHILE hunting for a new home, Ethan Benton had two familiar priorities -- larger space and lower rent. title: THE HUNT; No Roommates, Lots of Bikes

body: THE Brooklyn real estate market has turned into a bundle of contradictions in recent months. title: Brooklyn: A Bargain Hunter's Guide

body: All over the city yesterday, extremely valuable parking spaces were grabbed by -- there is no polite way of saying this -- out-and-out granola eaters. title: Man Is Killed on Return To Brooklyn Neighborhood

title: The Retailer Next Door

title: Fort Greene/Clinton Hill; In the Details, a Small-Town Feel

title: Brooklyn Heights; Wanted: A School of Their Own

title: Cracker-Barrel 2.0

body: WHEN people ask where I live, I tailor my answer to my audience. If someone with children is asking, I'll answer, ''Park Slope,'' as if I had just won the lottery. title: The Park Slope Parent Trap

title: The Handwriting on the Road: An Artist Draws the Flood Line

title: It Takes Money

title: MEDIA TALK; The Latest Must-Have for Yuppies: A Blog About the Neighborhood

body: SOON after renovating their brownstone in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, in blow-out modern style two years ago -- with a concrete floor, a back wall of glass and not one scrap of period trim -- Kirsa Phillips and Doug Cardoni opened it up to a local house tour. Later, Ms. Phillips went to brownstoner.com, a blog devoted to historic Brooklyn brownstones,
title: Clean and Spare Or True to History?

body: A day after telling New Yorkers to stop ''griping'' over parking tickets issued to snowbound cars, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg apologized yesterday and promised to waive all such tickets issued in the two days after the storm. It was a rare concession for Mr. Bloomberg, who has refused to back down in the face of past outcries over a smoking ban, a
title: Mayor Relents, Forgiving Tickets On Iced-In Cars

body: News flash: after decades as a musical bedroom community, Brooklyn now has lots and lots of clubs and performance spaces, many having sprouted in only the last few years. This weekend and next, 14 of them are presenting some of their best homegrown acts for ''Brooklyn Next,'' a festival organized by the Brooklyn Academy of Music to promote Kings
title: The Listings: Feb. 16 - Feb. 22; 'BROOKLYN NEXT'

body: As drivers dug themselves out from Wednesday's modest but messy snowstorm, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg found himself on the defensive over the city's decision not to suspend alternate-side parking rules. That move had residents complaining that their cars were ticketed after plows buried them in snow. The mayor was at times curt, testy and defensive
title: After Storm, Parking Tickets and an Outcry

body: The stained-glass windows in the eccentric building at 4 Downing Street in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn are made from discarded salt shakers, ashtrays and coffee tables, bottles dug up in the backyard and the detritus of neighborhood car accidents. It is only from the inside that you can see the windows' brilliant colors. Arthur Wood, 75,
title: An Angel Is Pulled Closer to Earth
